title-group.article-title: Design and fabrication of a micro-actuator based on an electromagnetic membrane device

abstract.p: The purpose of this study is to develop a micro-actuator manufactured by microelectromechanical system-based fabrication and electroplating techniques. This actuator presents a novel technique in electromagnetic fabrication with a smaller physical size than its traditional counterparts and provides a faster response time at a lower cost. A micro-coil structure is released from FeCl3 etchant and bonded on a thin film (Parafilm ‘M’ Pechiney Plastic Packaging Inc.) to achieve an actuator-membrane structure. When an external AC power is applied to a micro-coil, a magnetic field is created to attract and repel through an NdFeB permanent magnet, and the displacement of the membrane is increased by AC. The results show that the measured magnetic field intensity weakens as the distance between the coil and the Gauss meter probe increases. However, it is observed that the magnetic field intensity does not increase linearly with the number of series coils, because of the distance between them.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A microelectromechanical system (MEMS) is very promising in micro-size and high-precision domains, and as the technology and body of research develop, the micromodule technique becomes mature and stable. Micro-actuators can be broadly classified as static, piezoelectric or electromagnetic, depending upon their mode of actuation (Ahmad et al., 2003; Gracias et al., 2000; Hao et al., 2002; Hickerson and Gharib, 2006; Hickerson et al., 2005; Huang et al., 2007; Joerger et al., 2001; Lagorce et al., 1999; Liu et al., 1994; Ma et al., 2008; Mirkin et al., 1996; Nair and Pradeep, 2002; Shahverdi et al., 2007; Sun and Xia, 2002; Valden et al., 1998; Xu et al., 2006; Yeo et al., 2008; Zhu et al., 2005).

Piezoelectric and electromagnetic actuators are mostly used in the microelectromechanical actuator domain, as the required frequency of general piezoelectric actuators is a few hundred to thousands of Hertz, the displacement is small and the production is somewhat difficult. The commonly used micro-actuators include electrostatic, electrothermal, piezoelectric and electromagnetic actuators. The electromagnetic actuator has become the new trend, as it can use direct and inverse effects, store very high energy density and provide a faster response, more accurate displacement and a higher driving force compared with electrostatic and electrothermal actuators. The main disadvantage of the piezoelectric actuator is that its deformation is limited within a strain of 10% of the length, which often results in inadequate deformation.

The required frequency of an electromagnetic actuator is only several tens to hundreds of Hertz; the displacement can be several tens of micrometres and production is relatively easy. Zhu et al. (2005) utilized a sol-gel method to fabricate thin piezoelectric films for the actuation of micro-cantilever arrays in hard disk devices. Xu et al. (2006) proposed a piezoelectric actuator based on a monolithic Pb(ZrTi)O3 layer for high-precision positioning applications. Liu et al. (1994) developed an active MEMS-based fluid control system incorporating surface micromachined magnetic actuators, and showed that the actuators were capable of achieving a large deflection (100 µm) under the application of magnetic force with a magnetic flux density of 1.76 KGauss at a 2.5-A current input. Lagorce et al. (1999) presented an actuator based on a polymer magnet, and demonstrated that a good agreement existed between its theoretical and experimental response; however, the use of the device was limited as it had a maximum deflection of just 20 µm as a pumping system.

In 2005, Hickerson et al. proposed a valveless impedance pump in which a net flow was induced by periodically pinching a flexible section asymmetrically from its ends. In their design, the optimized lengths of the elastic and inelastic sections were 1.91 and 15.2 cm, respectively. The same authors also constructed a one-dimensional wave model by which many of the characteristics exhibited by the experiments of impedance actuating could be predicted (Hickerson and Gharib, 2006). Yeo et al. (2008) presented an impedance pump utilizing a lead zirconate titanate (PZT) cantilever beam with a high-frequency actuation. Their microchannel had the dimensions of 15×3×0.4 mm3, and a flow rate of 36 µl/s. The valve impedance actuating effect was first reported by Gerhart Liebau in 1954 and numerically examined by Bozi and Propst (2003). Based on partially elastic rigid walls, the impedance pump operated by the interaction between travelling waves emitted from the compression and reflected waves at the impedance mismatched position exhibits a non-linear response to the actuating compression frequency and flow reversal with actuating frequencies at certain ranges.

However, despite the detailed analysis and optimized results of electromagnetic actuators and experimental ones presented in previous studies, the problem of the actuator utilizing a micro-electromagnetic mechanism featuring a magnetic diaphragm and a substrate patterned with a copper micro-coil has attracted relatively little attention in the literature. The electrical current through the micro-coil induces a magnetic force between the coil and the magnet electroplated on the diaphragm, which causes the diaphragm to deflect, thereby creating an actuation effect.

***The micro-actuator converts a controlled signal (e.g. voltage or current) into kinetic energy for actions (e.g. translation, swing, vertical vibration, etc). In an MEMS, the actuation principles of the micro-actuator include an electromagnetic type, an electrostatic type and a piezoelectric type. In particular, an electromagnetic micro-actuator with large deformation, excellent frequency response and processes similar to general semiconductor processes was the focus of previous researchers. However, not all types of micro-actuators have all of the above characteristics; the type chosen is related to the action principle of actuation, and the actuator is selected according to different requirements. This aim of this study was to construct an electromagnetic actuator with simple processes and large displacement. Producing a high-performance electromagnetic micro-actuator with large displacement would reduce the total volume, and the magnetic field intensity of the coils could be changed according to the requirements of experiments.

sec.title: Design and magnetic analysis
sec.p: The working principle of an electromagnetic actuator is to utilize the interaction between electricity and magnetism, as well as the principle of inter-attraction and mutual repulsion in the magnetic field. The schematic diagram of an electromagnetic actuator in Figure 1 shows where a magnetic field is generated when the DC passes through the conductor, and where a directional magnetic field is generated if the DC passes through the coil formed by the conductor. Generally speaking, the magnetic field intensity generated by the coil depends on the current intensity, coil density, number of turns and the central magnetic substance.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of operation of electromagnetic actuator.

sec.p: According to Ampere’s right-hand rule, when the supplied current is AC, the magnetic force generated by a flat coil varies with the current direction, and interacts with the magnetism on the coil and the lower NdFeB magnet to form upward or downward displacement. The number of turns, the size and selection of the conducting material should be determined in the design of the coil. The magnetic field intensity is controlled by the intensity of the supplied current, and the N–S pole direction is defined. Since the conducting material has a certain electrical resistance, there is a certain limitation. An electromagnetic actuator contains a flat coil, magnetic material and conducting wire.

In this study, the polydimethyl siloxane (PDMS) membrane edge was fixed, the centre was under an even load q, the peripheral membrane had a radius of 4 mm, the area under load was 1250 µm and the thickness was 80 µm. When DC or AC was supplied to the coil to generate a magnetic force, a displacement occurred as the magnet on the membrane was attracted or repelled. Figure 2 shows the membrane vision chart.

sec.title: Fabrication of the flat coil
sec.p: Figure 3 shows the specifications of the coil used in this study: the mask diagram was drawn using AutoCAD software, the white solid wire area in the figure is the coil size and the outer area enclosed by the section line is the light-tight part. The small circle diameter was 3950 µm, the wire thickness was 155 µm, the spacing was 125 µm and the number of turns was 10. The coil pattern was transferred to the copper foil substrate using optical lithography technology.

Copper metal was used as the conducting wire material because of its low resistance rate and high electromigration resistance, and because it can grow in multiple deposition modes or electroplating modes. Therefore, it has received scholarly attention regarding the multilayer metal interconnection of deep sub-micron modules. However, as the copper is likely to become oxidized in general environments, some application problems remain.

sec.title: Design and fabrication of micro-actuators
sec.p: Figure 4 shows the main production process of the micro-electromagnetic micro-actuator. The process substrate was copper foil film, with a thickness of 2.4 µm. The coil pattern was defined on the substrate surface by AZP4620 photoresist using optical lithography technology, and it was etched by ferric chloride solution to obtain a flexible micro-coil, as shown in Figure 5. In order to strengthen the characteristics of the magnetic field, the coil thickness was increased to 5.3 µm by electroplating, the electroplating bath was a copper sulphate solution and the coil thickness was increased using a voltage of 2 V, a current of 0.3 A, and an electroplating time of 20 min. The components were connected in series by silver colloid in the centre of the coil, and the conducting wire was led out by welding. Figure 5 shows the practical situation of the coil after etching the copper foil film.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of process of electromagnetic micro-actuator: (a) clean the copper foil substrate; (b) define coil pattern in photo process; (c) etching moulding and electroplating; (d) connect coils in series by using silver colloid; (e) combination packaging.

sec.p: The entire micro-actuator was moulded using a plastic shell with a diameter of 20 mm, a height of 10 mm and a wall thickness of 1.5 mm as the main structure of the external packaging, retaining the preset holes. The electroplated coil was cemented and fixed to the sealing film (Parafilm ‘M’ Pechiney Plastic Packaging Inc.): the thickness was about 10 µm, the conducting wire of coil was led out by a welding lead and the sealing film affixed to the coil structure was fixed to the plastic packaging shell of the micro-actuator as the actuating membrane, as shown in Figure 6.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: When there is a magnetic line, there is a magnetic field and magnetic field intensity. The stress of the unit magnetic pole in the magnetic field is the magnetic field intensity at that point. Figure 7 shows the magnetic field intensity obtained by supplying the coil with currents at different intensities. The measurement method is shown in Figure 8. The coil was placed at the z-axis lifting platform under a Gauss meter (5180 Gauss, F.W. Bell Inc.). The sensing probe was parallel to the platform, the DC power supply provided different fixed currents, the z-axis platform moves at intervals of 0.5 mm and the change in the magnetic field was measured by the Gauss meter. According to the experimental data, the measured magnetic field intensity weakened as the distance between the coil and the Gauss meter probe increased.

caption.p: Relation between magnetic field and distance.
Schematic diagram of measurement of magnetic field.

sec.p: Although the magnetic field intensity of a single coil can be strengthened by increasing the current, the coil is likely to be burnt by an excessive working current because of its size and material characteristics. Therefore, this study connected the coils in series and supplied the actuator with a low current to obtain the existing magnetic field intensity. Figure 9 shows the magnetic field intensity of one coil, two coils connected in series and four coils connected in series, measured by a Gauss meter at the origin distance. As shown in the figure, when the layer number of the coils changed from one to two in series, the magnetic field intensity obviously increased. The magnetic field intensity of 2.53 mT was obtained when a working current (1 A) was supplied. With four layer coils in series, the magnetic field intensity of 3.14 mT was generated when a 1-A current was supplied. Therefore, the magnetic field intensity increased as the quantity of series coils increased. However, it was observed that the magnetic field intensity did not increase linearly with the number of series coils, which was related to the distance between the series coils. When the series connection distance was too large, the lower magnetic field was reduced with the series connection distance; this phenomenon is reflected by the data in Figure 7.

caption.p: Magnetic field dependence at zero distance.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: We have designed and experimentally realized the membrane structure with a planar micro-coil for application in a micro-actuator. The combination of the structure elements incorporating an electromagnetically actuated membrane successfully pumped air or water. Electromagnetic micro-actuators will be extensively applied in the future. In addition to their diversified applications, microelectromechanical process technology will receive greater notice as its MEMS components, various micro-portable devices and nano-components meet future electricity requirements.

When the copper foil film in thickness of 2.4 µm was used as the coil layer, the drive current was 1 A, which generated a 1.62-mT magnetic field. However, as overheating inside the component burnt the substrate, the component suffered from heat damage from the high currents; thus, it did not meet the actuating component requirements. When series coils were used, only a 0.5-A drive current could enable the double layer and quadric-layer coils to generate 1.3 and 1.61 mT magnetic fields, respectively, with an operating voltage of only 1 V, and a very short component response time. In comparison to driving a high voltage to actuate the component, this actuator was more energy efficient and thus met the low-voltage requirement for MEMS technology.
